article:
"Meg, we need to talk."
    "Sure thing, Dad." 
    "I have been to the  _   several times over the last few days, and well, Meg, I have a brain cancer.'
    "Okay."    . 
    "Just okay?''
    "Yep, just okay."
    It was the second half of my senior year, that  _  in a girl's life when all the really big exciting events are happening. My final performance, my eighteenth birthday and my graduation,all   _  my mind in just two short months. 
    By my final performance Dad couldn't really give his full   _   on it, but he was there. He bravely sat through my birthday dinner. and he,   _  to get out of the hospital for my graduation.   _  those months, we both were caring about the same thing--me. His doctor said that by   _  on all my future events, it kept my dad   _  longer. Nine days after my high school graduation, my father died. 
    For the next two weeks after his   _  . I didn't leave my room. Finally, my mom came in, opened my blinds and gave me a letter.    
    It was from my father's doctor. He wrote about how my father   _  him to change his life and the way he worked. "...He was not   _  a patient to me. He   _   more for the people around him than he did his own   _   .I have never met someone who put everyone else first. He was the type of person I   _  to be."
    I was   _  . I came to know what I should do. 
    Days later, I got a job as a summer camp counselor. I   _  everything I had to these little kids, and slowly they helped to heal me without even   _   what they were doing. Their innocence had helped me   _   some of mine. 
    That summer   _   parts of the life my father led in his last few days. I had learned the   _   lesson my father was teaching me--in order to lead a fulfilling life, you must learn how to give of yourself to others.
